title: Seven to bring back Big Brother in new line-up
text:
"The whole purpose is to invest in content and obviously improve our performance," Mr Warburton said.

"[We're] very open about the fact that Sunday-to-Tuesday 7.30pm has been a problem, very open, very transparent and brutally frank ... there are too many poor program failures and we haven't lived up to our own standards."

Seven's new prime-time line-up for 2020 includes returning programming My Kitchen Rules: The Rivals, House Rules: High Stakes, Home and Away and Better Homes and Gardens.

New shows in prime-time will include Plate of Origin, an international cooking competition hosted by Mr Preston, Mr Mehigan and Manu Feildel, the return of Big Brother, a miniature golf competition show, based on the US ABC Network show, Mega Mini Golf, celebrity physical challenge show SAS: Who Dares Wins, Farmer Wants a Wife and Pooch Perfect, hosted by Rebel Wilson.

Big Brother originally started in the early 2000s on Network Ten and later had a brief stint on Nine. Farmer Wants a Wife was previously on Nine, publisher of The Australian Financial Review.

"Look at something like Big Brother and it's a global phenomenon, it's one of the last mega brands. That show alone will change the demographic profile of our network overnight," Mr Warburton siad.

"I think there's some power in those brands and there's power in reinventing some of our tentpoles."

Advertisement

New dramas for next year will also include RDFS, starring Justine Clarke, Rob Collins and Stephen Peacock, which is based around the personal lives of workers in the Royal Flying Doctor Service, as well as Between Two Worlds, from A Place to Call Home creator, Bevan Lee.

Many of Seven's new shows have been commissioned from outside production studios, something it had done much less of in recent years as it focused on its own Seven Studios business. Seven's new line up includes shows from Fremantle, Endemol Shine, Screentime and Eureka.

"The execution of our content-led growth strategy means Seven is delivering 52 weeks of premium content backed by a 30 per cent increase in investment into our tentpole programs and franchises," Mr Warburton said.

"Combined with our unmatched sport and news offerings, we will deliver exponential impact for Seven’s partners in 2020."

It's been a busy week for Seven. On Friday, the network announced a merger with Prime and the sale of its Western Australia radio business to Southern Cross Austereo for $28 million. On Monday, it finalised the $40 million sale of Pacific Magazines to Bauer Media.

The sales and all-scrip offer for Prime, which carries little debt and is forecast to make up to $25 million in EBITDA this financial year, will allow Seven to pay down its significant debt and improve its leverage ratio.
description: Seven West Media chief executive James Warburton is shaking up the network's prime time offering in a push to provide more quality content.
